content.name: Introduction
data: You may already be familiar with the principles of effective management decision making, and have a high level understanding of Machine Learning (ML) as well as the potential benefits this technology could have for your organisation. In this casebook we bring these two topics together to learn how to choose the right machine learning tool for a particular task.

Recall that the most important aspect when developing a project strategy is to fully understand the problem you are trying to solve. The same goes for ML projects. There is a wide range of ML tools available, each with distinct capabilities and requirements. As such, you must first determine and understand the specific objectives of a project, before considering your options. It’s also necessary to consider what data you have available. While it is always possible to do extra data collection to fit a given purpose, it is often more effective to work with what you have rather than embarking on costly and time consuming data gathering efforts

Once you have a solid understanding of your problem, your goals, and the resources available, you can start developing your ML strategy. But it is not as simple as just plugging one in and hoping for the best. Since each tool has different data requirements, you have to determine what additional data you may need, and consider how the data, new or old, should be processed for the strategy to be effective. This will inevitably require input from various teams within the business, who may in turn require their own considerations and resources to work effectively.

All these factors need to be accounted for and included in the project plan alongside a prediction for how the output of this project will be used to inform business decisions. In the next few sections, we will outline three fictional case studies that cover these nuances and interconnected decisions to illustrate how this process works in practice.

content.name: Case 1: Supervised clustering
data: A brick and mortar electronics store has recently implemented an online storefront to capture the ever growing base of customers that prefer to do their shopping online, but so far have seen limited growth in sales. They are hoping to increase sales through targeted online advertising and have determined that they will need to identify specific valuable customer segments to get the best return on investment (ROI) for this approach.

As they have been operating primarily with in store customers until now, they haven’t yet identified these customer segments and want to use ML to automate the process. Fortunately, they already have some customer data through an in store loyalty program as well as customer profiles set up for the online store, but this data is unlabeled and unsorted. For this reason, the manager put in charge of the project has determined that k-means clustering would be the best approach, as it is a specific clustering approach that takes unlabeled data points and groups them into distinct non-overlapping subgroups. This makes it particularly well suited for identifying unique customer segments. The team can then examine these segments to classify those that are most valuable to the business (Sagar, 2019).

This project will require quantitative data about customer demographics and sales made to these customers that can be pulled from the loyalty program and online store profiles which would require input from the sales, customer support, and analytics teams. The output will help identify customer segments and can be further processed to sort them according to how valuable these segments have been to the business in terms of sales, information that can then be used by the marketing team to shape advertising strategies that target people within this segment and help grow the business.

content.name: Case 2: Supervised categorising
data: A second hand car company is growing and the process of digitising customer data from physical paperwork is becoming more and more time consuming and costly at the data entry level. While they could simply upload scans of the documents to their servers, specific regulations around data privacy and Personally Identifiable Information (PII) require that certain data points be protected in some way, i.e. encryption. The manager charged with finding a way to automate this process knows that the company has already manually digitised a large number of customer data profiles and labelled the individual data points for each. They know that they could use this existing labelled dataset to train a supervised learning algorithm to categorise this labelled data and automatically flag and encrypt any PII included in the filled out forms. This kind of pattern recognition is one of a number of suitable applications for supervised learning through the application of something like a convolutional neural network (CNN) (sixsigma, n.d.).

While the particularities of designing, training, and implementing the model will be up to the tech team the manager will still need to interface with the legal and data security teams to identify exactly which data points should be identified as sensitive, as well as the teams responsible for data capture up until this point to access the necessary training information and insights into how customer data is captured and input into they system.

Proper implementation of this strategy will help to simplify operations of the business, saving time and money, while ensuring regulatory compliance and protecting the business from potential legal consequences and reputational damage in case of a data breach.

content.name: Case 3: Unsupervised sentiment analysis
data: The developers of an online live service multiplayer video game wishes to ensure that their future updates and improvements will be directly targeted at addressing the needs and desires of their playerbase. While they could simply send out binary surveys for this they also know that there is a large amount of existing player feedback online in the form of reviews on storefronts, as well as posts on social media and their own game forums.

The manager in charge of this project knows about sentiment analysis, a ML technique for identifying positivity and negativity metrics to text-based data snippets, a very useful tool for identifying user sentiment towards the existing state of a given product or service and even to show which ideas for future changes are most positively received (Dorfman, n.d.)

A proper implementation of this technology will help with identifying user needs, as well as discovering and planning necessary product improvements. But it will require input and some work from a number of different departments. Firstly the data will need to be gathered from the various sources identified. This could be company-owned sources such as their own private forums, but may also require interfacing with third parties, such as online storefronts or social media platforms to legally scrape relevant text posts relating to the game in question. This data will then also need to be sorted according to topic (responses to the latest map, gameplay changes, or monetization strategies for example), and this will require interfacing with marketing, customer support, social media, legal, and data teams depending on the particularities of the data sources as well as potentially reaching out to the tech team to see whether existing data sorting algorithms could be used to help label the data before textual analysis.

An effective implementation of this strategy will help with identifying and contextualizing user opinion and identifying potentially desirable improvements to the product, directing business strategy towards enhancing the customer experience and improving products and services.

data.data: Choosing a particular ML tool or application for your business project is a matter of understanding the problem and particularities of the data available to you. The three examples discussed are far from comprehensive, and your projects may not fit neatly with any of these solutions. The following infographic illustrates a simplified flowchart that helps with the high-level considerations involved in this decision-making process.

data: The five broad categories of ML tools discussed in this course thus far are the following:
Classification: Classification models are created from labeled datasets. These tools attempt to place new data into the categories defined when creating the model with the labeled data.
Clustering: Clustering models are created from unlabelled datasets. These tools attempt to find groups of data points to cluster similarly and then fit new data into one of these clusters.
Regression: Regression models are used to create predictive models with quantitative data that link an independent variable with several dependent variables that affect it.

Sentiment analysis: Sentiment analysis is a machine learning tool that attempts to sort text data into positive, neutral, and negative categories. This is often used in the analysis of product reviews or satisfaction surveys.
Topic modeling: Topic modeling tools attempt to scan sets of text for patterns of words or phrases that best categorize the content of the text data.

data.data: Each of these have multiple specialized applications and you can find more detailed information on them in the supplementary materials in the downloads folder. For now it is important to know what they are used for, and what the data and operational requirements are for each.

Pick one of the ML categories listed above and do some research into specific tools and strategies that may fall under it. K-means clustering, for example, is just one of a number of clustering strategies. See if you can identify the particular nuances that differentiates these tools and which would be most applicable to a business objective in your context.

content.name: Conclusion
data: Implementing ML into your business or using it for a particular project isn’t a simple case of plug-and-play. There are many aspects to consider when choosing a suitable strategy and it requires a solid understanding of not only your goals but also the data requirements and the personnel needed to meet those requirements. If you consider these questions well and understand the various moving parts, you will be well on your way to improving your business through the use of these diverse and useful tools. In the next activity, you will have the opportunity to practice this thinking for yourself, bringing together all that you have learned in this course so far.

data: Now that you have a better understanding of how to choose and implement an ML strategy for a particular business project, it is time to engage with this in practice.
